title: 105_s391
content: The Act is titled the "Mississippi Sioux Tribes Judgment Fund Distribution Act of 1998" and includes definitions. The Act defines key terms such as "covered Indian tribe," "Fund Account," "Secretary," and "tribal governing body." It also specifies the distribution and use of funds by the Sisseton and Wahpeton Tribes of Sioux Indians. Funds from Public Law 90-352 for Sisseton and Wahpeton Tribes of Sioux Indians must be distributed according to this Act. SEC. 4. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS TO TRIBES. The Secretary will transfer an aggregate amount to the Fund Account for the benefit of governing bodies, determined by subtracting 71.6005 percent of funds described in section 3 from the total funds available. The Secretary will allocate transferred funds to accounts in the Fund Account for tribal governing bodies as follows: 28.9276% to Spirit Lake Tribe of North Dakota, 57.3145% to Sisseton and Wahpeton Sioux Tribe of South Dakota, and 13.7579% to another account. 13.7579 percent of allocated funds will benefit the tribal governing body of the Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes of the Fort Peck Reservation in Montana. The Sisseton and Wahpeton Sioux Council will act as the governing body for the distribution of funds. The Secretary of the Interior will establish necessary accounts in the Fund Account for distributing funds to tribal governing bodies. SEC. 5. USE OF DISTRIBUTED FUNDS. Funds allocated for a covered Indian tribe under section 4 cannot be used for per capita payments. The funds can only be used by the tribal governing body for economic development, resource development, beneficial programs for tribe members, and payment of existing obligations or debts related to approved activities. The curr_chunk discusses the payment of attorneys' fees or expenses for covered Indian tribes related to litigation arising from Public Law 92-555. The amount of fees paid by a tribe cannot exceed 10% of the funds distributed to them under section 4. This provision applies to specific contracts and situations outlined in the text. The curr_chunk discusses the management and investment of funds distributed to covered Indian tribes under specific contracts approved by the Secretary. Tribes can withdraw funds at their discretion, subject to certain conditions. The curr_chunk discusses the distribution of funds to Indian tribes under specific contracts, exempting them from certain requirements. Payments made under this Act will not affect eligibility for Federal benefits. The Act exempts covered Indian tribes, households, or individuals from having payments affect their eligibility for Federal benefits or services. SEC. 7. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS TO LINEAL DESCENDANTS. The Secretary shall distribute funds to lineal descendants of the Sisseton and Wahpeton Tribes of Sioux Indians, amounting to 71.6005 percent of the funds described in section 3, with adjustments made if the number of certified descendants is less than 2,588. The Secretary will distribute funds to lineal descendants of the Sisseton and Wahpeton Tribes of Sioux Indians, with adjustments based on the number of certified descendants. An amount equal to any reduction in distribution will be added to the available funds for distribution to eligible individuals. Verification of ancestry is required for enrollment on the roll of lineal descendants after January 1, 1998. The Secretary must certify that each enrolled lineal descendant can trace ancestry to a specific Sisseton or Wahpeton Mississippi Sioux Tribe ancestor listed on various historical rolls. Amendments are made to Public Law 92-555 to accommodate these requirements. Amendments are made to Public Law 92-555, including changes to section 1300d-4(a) and section 201(b) related to the Mississippi Sioux Tribes Judgment Fund Distribution Act of 1998. SEC. 8. JURISDICTION; PROCEDURE. In actions challenging distributions under the Act, covered Indian tribes can intervene to defend or challenge the distributions made to lineal descendants. Exclusive original jurisdiction for such actions lies with specific US District Courts. The Act allows for challenges to the constitutionality or validity of distributions, with actions consolidated and jurisdiction granted to the US Court of Federal Claims. Covered Indian tribes must be notified within 30 days of a claim being raised, and there is a statute of limitations on such actions. The Act establishes a statute of limitations of 365 days for filing claims related to distributions. A special rule applies if a final judgment favors lineal descendants, where 100 percent of funds are distributed to them. The Act sets a 365-day statute of limitations for filing claims on distributions. If a final judgment favors lineal descendants, 100 percent of funds are distributed to them within 180 days. The Secretary distributes funds to covered Indian tribes based on specified percentages. Covered tribes cannot bring claims related to fund distribution under Public Law 92-555, but can intervene in relevant actions. The curr_chunk states that jurisdiction of courts in subsection (b) may be limited to hear and determine certain claims.
